2.text: “Truly I know that it is so, but how can man be just with God?

3.text: If he is pleased to contend with him, he can’t answer him one time in a thousand.

4.text: God who is wise in heart, and mighty in strength: who has hardened himself against him, and prospered?

5.text: He removes the mountains, and they don’t know it, when he overturns them in his anger.

6.text: He shakes the earth out of its place. Its pillars tremble.

7.text: He commands the sun, and it doesn’t rise, and seals up the stars.

8.text: He alone stretches out the heavens, and treads on the waves of the sea.

9.text: He makes the Bear, Orion, and the Pleiades, and the rooms of the south.

10.text: He does great things past finding out; yes, marvelous things without number.

11.text: Behold, he goes by me, and I don’t see him. He passes on also, but I don’t perceive him.

12.text: Behold, he snatches away. Who can hinder him? Who will ask him, ‘What are you doing?’

13.text: “God will not withdraw his anger. The helpers of Rahab stoop under him.

14.text: How much less shall I answer him, And choose my words to argue with him?

15.text: Though I were righteous, yet I wouldn’t answer him. I would make supplication to my judge.

16.text: If I had called, and he had answered me, yet I wouldn’t believe that he listened to my voice.

17.text: For he breaks me with a storm, and multiplies my wounds without cause.

18.text: He will not allow me to catch my breath, but fills me with bitterness.

19.text: If it is a matter of strength, behold, he is mighty! If of justice, ‘Who,’ says he, ‘will summon me?’

20.text: Though I am righteous, my own mouth shall condemn me. Though I am blameless, it shall prove me perverse.

21.text: I am blameless. I don’t respect myself. I despise my life.

22.text: “It is all the same. Therefore I say he destroys the blameless and the wicked.

23.text: If the scourge kills suddenly, he will mock at the trial of the innocent.

24.text: The earth is given into the hand of the wicked. He covers the faces of its judges. If not he, then who is it?

25.text: “Now my days are swifter than a runner. They flee away, they see no good,

26.text: They have passed away as the swift ships, as the eagle that swoops on the prey.

27.text: If I say, ‘I will forget my complaint, I will put off my sad face, and cheer up;’

28.text: I am afraid of all my sorrows, I know that you will not hold me innocent.

29.text: I shall be condemned. Why then do I labor in vain?

30.text: If I wash myself with snow, and cleanse my hands with lye,

31.text: yet you will plunge me in the ditch. My own clothes shall abhor me.

32.text: For he is not a man, as I am, that I should answer him, that we should come together in judgment.

33.text: There is no umpire between us, that might lay his hand on us both.

34.text: Let him take his rod away from me. Let his terror not make me afraid;

35.text: then I would speak, and not fear him, for I am not so in myself.
